questions.question: The DC load line on the I_C vs V_CE plane has a slope of:
options: −R_C/(R_C + R_E)
questions.explanation: From KVL: V_CC = I_C(R_C + R_E) + V_CE. Rearranging: I_C = −V_CE/(R_C+R_E) + V_CC/(R_C+R_E). The slope is −1/(R_C+R_E), which is negative because increasing V_CE decreases I_C along the line.

questions.question: To draw the DC load line, you need two points. What are the V_CE-intercept and I_C-intercept?
options: V_CE = V_CC (at I_C=0) and I_C = V_CC/R_C (at V_CE=0)
V_CE = V_CC (at I_C=0) and I_C = V_CC/(R_C+R_E) (at V_CE=0)
V_CE = 0.7 V (at I_C=0) and I_C = V_CC/R_E (at V_CE=0)
V_CE = V_CC/2 and I_C = V_CC/(2R_C)
questions.explanation: At I_C = 0: V_CE = V_CC (all supply voltage appears across the transistor). At V_CE = 0: I_C = V_CC/(R_C+R_E) (maximum possible current through the resistors). Connect these two points with a straight line.

questions.question: The Q-point on the output characteristics is the intersection of:
options: The DC load line and the base current I_BQ characteristic curve
The DC load line and the AC load line
The saturation line and the cutoff line
The DC load line and the V_CE axis
questions.explanation: The Q-point satisfies both constraints simultaneously: the circuit constraint (DC load line) and the transistor's physics (I_BQ characteristic curve). Their intersection gives (V_CEQ, I_CQ).

questions.question: To obtain the AC equivalent circuit, you should:
options: Open-circuit all capacitors and keep V_CC
Short-circuit all capacitors, short V_CC to ground, and open any DC current sources
Remove all resistors and keep only the BJT
Replace the BJT with its DC model
questions.explanation: At signal frequencies: capacitors → short (X_C ≈ 0), DC voltage sources → short to ground (they have no AC content), DC current sources → open (no AC content). This leaves only the AC signal path and the AC impedances.

questions.question: Why is the AC load line steeper than the DC load line?
options: Because V_CC is larger for AC signals
Because the bypass capacitor shorts part of R_E, so the AC sees a smaller total resistance (R_C + r_e1 < R_C + R_E)
Because β is larger at AC frequencies
Because the coupling capacitor adds impedance
questions.explanation: The DC load line has slope −1/(R_C+R_E) including all of R_E. The bypass capacitor across R_E2 shorts it at AC frequencies, so the AC load line has slope −1/(R_C+r_e1) where r_e1 < R_E. Smaller denominator → steeper slope.

questions.question: When a signal is applied, the operating point moves along which line?
options: The DC load line
The AC load line
The I_BQ characteristic curve
A path between both load lines
questions.explanation: The signal creates small variations around the Q-point. At signal frequencies, the effective resistance is the AC resistance (with bypass caps shorted), so the operating point traces the AC load line, not the DC load line.

questions.question: What limits the maximum undistorted output signal swing?
options: The supply voltage V_CC only
The distance from the Q-point to whichever limit (saturation or cutoff) is closer along the AC load line
The beta of the transistor
The coupling capacitor's reactance
questions.explanation: The signal swings along the AC load line from the Q-point towards saturation (V_CE ≈ 0.2 V) in one direction and cutoff (I_C = 0) in the other. The maximum symmetric swing is limited by whichever boundary is closer. If clipping occurs in one direction first, the output is asymmetrically distorted.

questions.question: For V_CC = 12 V, R_C = 4 kΩ, R_E = 2 kΩ, what is the I_C-intercept of the DC load line?
options: 3 mA
2 mA
6 mA
4 mA
questions.explanation: I_C-intercept = V_CC/(R_C + R_E) = 12/(4k + 2k) = 12/6k = 2 mA. This is the maximum possible DC collector current in this circuit (when V_CE = 0).

questions.question: If the Q-point is at (V_CEQ = 8 V, I_CQ = 0.67 mA) on a DC load line from (12V, 0) to (0, 2mA), how far can V_CE swing towards saturation?
options: 8 V
4 V
questions.explanation: V_CE can decrease from V_CEQ = 8 V down to V_CE(sat) ≈ 0.2 V before the transistor saturates. That's a swing of 8 − 0.2 = 7.8 V towards saturation. Towards cutoff, V_CE can increase to V_CC = 12 V, a swing of 12 − 8 = 4 V. The maximum symmetric swing is the smaller: 4 V.

questions.question: What happens to the DC load line if R_C is doubled (R_E unchanged)?
options: The line shifts to the right with the same slope
The V_CE-intercept stays at V_CC, the I_C-intercept decreases, and the slope becomes less steep
Both intercepts double
The load line doesn't change because it depends only on V_CC
questions.explanation: V_CE-intercept = V_CC (unchanged — doesn't depend on R_C). I_C-intercept = V_CC/(R_C+R_E) decreases because the denominator increases. Slope = −1/(R_C+R_E) becomes less steep (smaller magnitude). The line effectively pivots around the V_CC point on the V_CE axis.
